awd_titl_txt: GP-IMPACT: Geosciences Streamlined Pipeline And Research for Community Colleges (Geo-SPARCC)
awd_abstract_narration:
Increased participation in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) is an area of national concern, especially as enrollment in STEM disciplines and development of the STEM workforce is not keeping pace with the need. This is particularly true in the geosciences where the lack of diversity compounds the problem. This Geosciences Streamlined Pipeline And Research for Community Colleges (Geo-SPARCC) at Mississippi State University (MSU) fills a gap in the awareness of and education in the geosciences through collaboration with the State's community colleges. Mississippi is a rural state with a strong community college system, enrolling greater than 75,000 students, ~42% from underrepresented groups (majority African American). Mississippi State University collaborates with Jones County Junior College to develop engaging online versions of introductory geology courses, which will be available to all community college students through Mississippi's Virtual Community College Consortium. The Geo-SPARCC project also develops an e-mentoring network to recruit community college students to consider geosciences degrees and careers, and facilitate their transfer into a 4-year university. The MS Virtual Community College Consortium fosters sustainability of Geo-SPARCC and has the potential to help significantly increase the number of underserved and underrepresented populations in the geosciences.

The Geosciences Streamlined Pipeline And Research for Community Colleges (Geo-SPARCC) project proposes a collaboration between Mississippi State University (MSU) and Mississippi's community colleges (CCs) to develop a pathway from 2 year to 4 year institutions via online instruction and e-mentoring. Geo-SPARCC will 1) interest/recruit CC students in geosciences through engaging online physical/historical geology courses; 2) provide individualized research and field opportunities within online courses; and 3) develop an e-mentoring/social media program between MSU Geosciences faculty/graduate students and CC students. Jones County Junior College (JCJC), the lead CC on the Geo-SPARCC project, will make Geo-SPARCC's online geology courses available through the Mississippi Virtual Community College (MSVCC), providing access for students at all 15 Mississippi CCs as well as MS high school students in dual enrollment courses. The Geo-SPARCC online courses will include personalized research/field components where students conduct independent research and geocaching, and opportunities to participate in MSU Geosciences-led field excursions. Career video vignettes included in the online course design will introduce students to geosciences employment opportunities. Geo-SPARCC further provides CC students with directed individual study research opportunities that can culminate in student presentations at the Mississippi Academy of Science annual conference. Sustainability is ensured since the Geo-SPARCC online courses will be offered in perpetuity by JCJC through the MSVCC, with MSU collaborating with JCJC beyond the Geo-SPARCC project to provide credentialed adjunct instructors to teach the online courses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
The State of Mississippi hosts the oldest community college system in the US, but prior to the Geo-SPARCC project, students were unable to take introductory geoscience courses at Mississippi community colleges. This put them at a disadvantage in learning about geoscience majors and career opportunities and when transferring into a geoscience program at a 4-year institution. Since many Mississippians begin their higher education at a community college, Geo-SPARCC developed online physical and historical geology lecture and laboratory courses, hosted by Jones College, and made available to all community college students through the Mississippi Virtual Community College consortium. Mississippi contains the largest percentage of African Americans of any US state, and through place-placed interactive online courses, Geo-SPARCC sought to increase interest in geosciences and the number of underrepresented groups in geoscience majors and careers.

Every unit in the physical and historical online geology courses begins with a brief video introduction (In MISSISSIPPI!) that connects the content to the state's natural features. Units also include "Meet a Geoscientist" videos that showcase potential geoscience career opportunities. Each unit requires students to move beyond the confines of their computer and apply geological content. For example, physical geology students search for local examples of mass wasting and build slime glaciers, while historical geology students find fossils in local Paleozoic gravel and calculate the amount of salt deposited when the Gulf of Mexico was formed. Students must complete a field project by either joining an excursion with their video instructors and/or professional geoscientists or investigating their local area through geocaching.  

Through Spring 2023, a total of 121 students from four Mississippi community colleges enrolled in the interactive, online courses, with some students later transferring to a university to major in Earth Science or Geology. These online courses continue to be offered sustainably beyond the Geo-SPARCC project. Geo-SPARCC has the potential to provide online quality geosciences instruction through the MVCC for years to come.


Last Modified: 10/12/2023
Modified by: Renee Clary

Images (1 of )
  • Geo-SPARCC hosted field excursions where GLY students could meet their on-camara video instructors and learn from professional geoscientists as they completed their field project activities.
    Renee Clary
    Copyrighted
    Renee Clary
    GLY Students at Smith County Lime Pit
  • Geo-SPARCC Geosciences Day brought GLY students to the Mississippi Museum of Natural Science (MMNS) for behind-the-scenes tours, and discussions with professional geoscientists in Mississippi. George Phillips, MMNS Paleontology Curator (left) shows the MMNS paleontology preparation laboratory.
    Renee Clary
    Copyrighted
    Renee Clary
    Geo-SPARCC Geosciences Day
  • Geo-SPARCC results were shared at 11 professional conferences, including the Mississippi Academy of Sciences. In 2023, Clary (left) and Nagel (right) discussed the Geo-SPARCC online courses, and recruited colleagues to promote and publicize the course availability.
    Renee Clary
    Copyrighted
    Renee Clary
    Geo-SPARCC Presentation at Mississippi Academy of Sciences
  • Geo-SPARCC PIs Nagel and Clary visited and filmed geology content across Mississippi that is showcased at the beginning of every module. At Red Bluff, The Grand Canyon of Mississippi, the sandstone readily erodes.
    Renee Clary
    Copyrighted
    Renee Clary
    In MISSISSIPPI! Geo-SPARCC at Red Bluff
  • Geo-SPARCC included a short interview with a geoscientist in every course module. Kelisha Stamps discussed how she became interested in geology and pursued a geology degree. Clary conducted the Stamps interview at Smith County Lime Pit, a popular field excursion destination.
    Athena Nagel
    Copyrighted
    Renee Clary
    Geo-SPARCC Meet a Geoscientist
